sub_topic: Finding the inverse of a matrix
message_1:
Determine the inverse of the following 3x3 matrix:
$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -3 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$
message_2:
To find the inverse of a 3x3 matrix, we first need to find its determinant. The determinant of the given matrix is:

$$\det(A) = \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 2 & -3 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 \\ 2 & 1 & 0 \end{vmatrix} = 1\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 4 \\ 1 & 0 \end{vmatrix} - 2\begin{vmatrix} 0 & 4 \\ 2 & 0 \end{vmatrix} - 3\begin{vmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 1(1\cdot0 - 4\cdot1) - 2(0\cdot0 - 4\cdot2) - 3(0\cdot1 - 1\cdot2) = -4 + 16 + 6 = 18$$

Since the determinant is non-zero, the matrix has an inverse. Now, we need to find the adjugate matrix, which is the transpose of the matrix of cofactors. The matrix of cofactors is:

$$C = \begin{bmatrix} C_{11} & C_{12} & C_{13} \\ C_{21} & C_{22} & C_{23} \\ C_{31} & C_{32} & C_{33} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 4 \\ 1 & 0 \end{vmatrix} & -\begin{vmatrix} 0 & 4 \\ 2 & 0 \end{vmatrix} & \begin{vmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\ -\begin{vmatrix} 2 & -3 \\ 1 & 0 \end{vmatrix} & \begin{vmatrix} 1 & -3 \\ 2 & 0 \end{vmatrix} & -\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\ \begin{vmatrix} 2 & -3 \\ 1 & 4 \end{vmatrix} & -\begin{vmatrix} 1 & -3 \\ 0 & 4 \end{vmatrix} & \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 \end{vmatrix} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 8 & 2 \\ 6 & 6 & -3 \\ 14 & 4 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

Now, we transpose the matrix of cofactors to get the adjugate matrix:

$$adj(A) = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 6 & 14 \\ 8 & 6 & 4 \\ 2 & -3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

Finally, we divide each element of the adjugate matrix by the determinant to get the inverse:

$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{18}\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 6 & 14 \\ 8 & 6 & 4 \\ 2 & -3 & 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & \frac{1}{3} & \frac{7}{9} \\ \frac{4}{9} & \frac{1}{3} & \frac{2}{9} \\ \frac{1}{9} & -\frac{1}{6} & \frac{1}{18} \end{bmatrix}$$

So, the inverse of the given matrix is:

$$A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & \frac{1}{3} & \frac{7}{9} \\ \frac{4}{9} & \frac{1}{3} & \frac{2}{9} \\ \frac{1}{9} & -\frac{1}{6} & \frac{1}{18} \end{bmatrix}$$
